prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator resolution is set to the coarsest binning allowed in the FDM mode. The TDM resolution is too coarse to resample at ~25 km/s scales, but the typical 7 km/s resolution of the FDM mode is adequate for these galaxies. For all sources other than 0243 we must preserve the FDM resolution in both sidebands because of the presence of CO in the other sideband.

The targets of this proposal have been observed at 0.5" resolution with ALMA in cycle 0. The largest angular scale is taken directly from those data.
The proposed 0.2" angular resolution for all sources was determined from the need to achieve effective source-plane resolution of ~1-200pc to study the properties of individual star formation regions. Allowing for slight variations between sources, this provided the best match to that scale.

The sensitivity of these observations was determined from the expected surface brightness of the CII line after lensing. All targets in this proposal have a) robust lens models based on ALMA data, b) measurements of CII luminosity and linewidth from APEX. From these inputs, we are able to calculate the line peak brightness and number of beams over which it will be spread (on average). Past line observations suggest that the CII will be more extended than the dust from which we derive the lens models, so we have increased the assumed solid angle of the CII, which (conservatively) decreases the flux per beam. The velocity channelization of 25 km/s is chosen to ensure that the spatial and spectral resolution probe similar structures. Here we take the rotational velocity gradient (up to 25 km/s per 100pc) and residual dispersion (~50 km/s) from the Swinbank et al. (2011) observations of a cluster-lensed DSFG (the "Eyelash") to estimate the relevant spatial channel size. Considering the line peak flux and the channel width, we require an average SNR of 10/beam. For the two paired sources, because we can only pick one sensitivity target, we attempt to balance the two source depths.

The correlator resolution is set to the coarsest binning allowed in the FDM mode. The TDM resolution is too coarse to resample at ~25 km/s scales, but the typical 7 km/s resolution of the FDM mode is adequate for these galaxies. For all sources other than 0243 we must preserve the FDM resolution in both sidebands because of the presence of CO in the other sideband.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The ISM in the most massive galaxies at high redshifts was substantially different than the ISM of star-forming galaxies today. While the most intense bouts of star formation occurred in dust-enshrouded objects, models of galaxy formation have great difficulty in forming realistic populations of galaxies that simultaneously match observed number counts and other galaxy properties. Here, we propose 0.2" resolution observations of the [CII] 158um emission line in 7 z>4 gravitationally lensed galaxies selected from the SPT 1.4mm survey. By reconstructing the [CII] emission on scales of ~100pc and 25km/s, we will determine valuable structural parameters of the ISM, including the pressure, cloud sizes, stability parameter, and global kinematics. By comparing with maps of the continuum (tracing star formation) at the same resolution, we will explore the gas depletion timescales and local Kennicutt-Schmidt relation. Finally, we expect to detect on the order of one additional continuum source and one additional line source at the same redshift as the primary galaxy in every pointing, yielding valuable information about the clustering of extreme star-bursting galaxies at high redshift.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00942.S, "Shut It Down: Probing Molecular Feedback in z~4.5 Dusty, Star-forming Galaxies", PI Spilker 2015.1.01238.S, "An [OI] 63?m survey of lensed dusty star-forming galaxies from the SPT survey", PI De Breuck 2015.1.01328.S, "Revealing the Gravitational Imprint of Dark Matter Subhalos with ALMA Observations of Strongly Lensed submm Galaxies", PI Hezaveh
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
